text: Number 661, Hellenic Lines against Rhoditis.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Well, is this not a situation which fluctuates from time to time depending on the demands for shipping?
Of course it does.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please this honorable --
Mr. Stahl.
Thank you, Your Honor.
That's the end of (Inaudible), you mean the owner of the ship?
Yes, Your Honor.
Where was the ship built?
Some of them in Japan, some of them in Germany, some of them I believe in this country.
Are any of them -- are any of them American built ships?
Yes, the very first five ships he bought were American Liberty ships which incidentally he bought from the United States Government.
I don't think an individual owned those ships.
That is correct.
So an individual doesn't own a ship.
The corporation --
-- owns the ship.
The registered owner is a Panamanian corporation --
Hellenic Lines Limited is the owner of the ships, am I correct?
Not the registered owner, no, Your Honor.
Universal Cargo Carriers?
Yes, it's potentially Universal Cargo Carriers Corporation which is a Panamanian corporation.
99 and what?
Just 99%.
He only owns 99%.
That's all.
He is a -- he is a --
What's Panama have to do with it?
Absolutely nothing except that is a symbol of convenience for this man because apparently of its lax shipping laws.
You have to be an American citizen at organizing corporation, 99% of the stock and what do they do for Panama, what they get from Panama?
He registered the ownership of 19 of 22 of his United States line of service vessels to a Panamanian corporation.
How long has he been a resident of this country?
25 years and he's been a domiciliary for that long and for the last 19 he has had permanent resident alien status.
Who is the owner of this other 1% of the stock?
His son who also lives here, a Mr. Gregory.
Where does his son live?
Also in New York.
He's not an American citizen, is he?
I don't believe his son is either although the --
Neither one is?
Neither one are American citizens, that is correct.
They're both Greek nationals, aren't they?
I would not call them nationals.
Well, where did they get a passport if they want to travel?
Well, I'm not familiar with the regulations for foreign travel, Your Honor.
But they are Greek nationals who were domiciled in the United States.
Well, it is but I argue that the domicile in the United States in this case --
Well, you may argue the significance of the domicile but that doesn't change the fact that he's a Greek national.
No, Your Honor.
He's a Greek national who chooses to live in this country with his family.
Yes, Your Honor.
I think I have a couple of minutes, Your Honor.
Mr. Estabrook, are they part of the reason for the large number of Greek seaman be the factor that there are cheaper labor?
One -- one of the points, things Your Honor, there are over 100,000 Greek seamen and one of the largest groups of seamen in the world and I think the principal --
Well, is the standard wages for Greek seamen equal to that of the United States, the answer is no.
Of course not.
But we're dealing with the United States here.
It is lower and --
Does he pay taxes in Greece?
Yes, he does, Your Honor.
And does he pay on these insurance policies over there, working compensation clauses, or do the seamen pay that?
He pays on -- he pays that there.
I thought you said the seamen pay them.
The seamen -- no, the seamen contribute and he contributes to a seaman's pension fund, NAT, N-A-T.
Oh!
No, that's not involved here.
But do you agree that he will end up with a $160.00 he got if he went back to Greece?
He'll get more than that Your Honor.
How much?
I don't know.
No.
He gets paid while he's working?
He gets paid while he's disabled.
But he's working now?
He's working now.
So what would he get now?
No, he'd get more than that.
But you don't know how much more?
I don't know how much more and if there's any -- I don't -- this Court found no disability so he'd get --
Couldn't I assume from the fact that you're defending this case that there would be more?
We're defending this case because as a matter of principle --
I see.
-- he'd get more.
But you would be making the same argument whether the -- suppose that this individual was a Greek or an American, wouldn't you?
On this ship, yes.
So it's really irrelevant about the allegiance of the majority stockholder of this corporation, your argument would be the same?
That's right.
And you're -- and the owner of the ship anyway is a Panamanian corporation?
All of the stock of which is owned by a Greek Corporation.
By a Greek Corporation and 99% of which is owned by --
A Greek citizen domiciled in this country.
But those things are really irrelevant, aren't they, to your argument because as long as the ship is registered in Greece --
That's right.
-- carrying the foreign flag and a Greek crew --
Yes.
-- it's irrelevant to your argument who the owner is.
That's -- yes, that follows the argument in the McCulloch.
You say there are no such things as flags of convenience.
I say there are many flags of convenience but this isn't one of them.
This isn't one of them because --
Because of the fact the Greek Government is responsible for the good order and maintenance of the ship.
And that -- and that anybody from anywhere around the world can go and --
No, no.
And get -- and get their ships that are -- that may be built abroad, owned abroad and licensed in Greece?
No, Your Honor.
It is not true here though, is it?
Yes, it is.
I thought you said 99% was owned by one man who lives in this country --
And is a Greek citizen.
And 1% by his son.
No, I will say that 99% --
What?
I will say that 99% was owned by one man --
In this country?
A Greek citizen with allegiance to Greece.
But he lives in this country.
Yes, he does.
And did his business in this country?
Yes, but he is a Greek citizen.
Had been living here many years?
Yes, Your Honor.
May I ask you just one other question about the contract?
Under the Jones Act, it would not be valid.
It would not be valid.
There's a specific provision of the Jones Act.
That's right.
Yes.
Alright, that's I wanted to know.
Thank you, Mr. Estabrook.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Thank you, Mr. Stahl.
